title: WeWork debacle: how Awfis, IndiQube, other Indian co-working startups can build viable businesses
text:
The WeWork meltdown has put co-working business models under the lens globally. Indian co-working startups are de-risking and cautiously scaling up. They are wooing SMEs and large enterprises with satellite offices and ancillary services, and building revenue-sharing models. But nobody has quite cracked it yet.

A WeWork facility in the Brooklyn borough of New York City

not a space where becoming a market leader soon has any bearing on becoming successful in the future. “Tomorrow, if someone gives us a lot of billions, maybe even we would not be able to think clearly,” says the promoter of leading co-working player. The nascent industry has a roller-coaster ride ahead. ( Graphics by Mohammad Arshad) It was almost considered too big to fail, given its giant footprint in the real-estate market of some of the biggest metropolitan cities around the globe. Indeed, up until recently, WeWork claimed to be the largest real-estate tenant in New York, London, and Washington. But in the run-up to its planned IPO, the shared-workplace behemoth finally appears to have cavednot a space where becoming a market leader soon has any bearing on becoming successful in the future. “Tomorrow, if someone gives us a lot of billions, maybe even we would not be able to think clearly,” says the promoter of leading co-working player. The nascent industry has a roller-coaster ride ahead. ( Graphics by Mohammad Arshad)
